results.name: a(n) is the smallest number k > 1 such that 1^(k-1) + 2^(k-1) + ... + n^(k-1) == n (mod k).
comment: a(n) = 2 if and only if n == {0, 1} (mod 4).
By the Agoh-Giuga conjecture, if a(n-1) = n, then n is a prime.
It seems that if a(n) > n, then a(n) is a prime (the next prime after n).
If a(n) = n, then n is in A121707. These numbers are 35, 143, 187, 215, ...
Conjecture: all composite terms of the sequence are A121707.
link: Chai Wah Wu, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000 (n = 1..1000 from Seiichi Manyama)
mathematica: a[n_] := Block[{k=2}, While[Mod[Sum[PowerMod[j, k-1, k], {j, n}], k] != Mod[n, k], k++]; k]; Array[a, 81] (* _Giovanni Resta_, Jul 29 2018 *)
